題目：Some people believe that it is good to share as much information as possible in scientific research, business and the academic world. Others believe that some information is too important or too valuable to be shared freely

People have different views about how we should spread knowledge. While some may think that it will be great when everyone can get whatever they want to learn freely, I believe that the owners of data have right to tell people who the authors trust.

There are various reasons why some people support the idea that free resources make the society better. For example, Germany is known for its reliable cars' engines. They may assert that if a car maker from Hong Kong can acquire the technologies of building a car from Germany, this will improve the overall cars' quality. Therefore, the whole world will benefit more if all skills are open to companies who want to learn them.

In spite of these arguments, I believe that some scientists discoveries, business secrets, and academic studies are too dangerous that they should be hidden. For instance, the methods, materials, and formulas of making an atomic bomb should not be revealed to all citizens, because if we do, bad countries may use them to threaten other places' safety.

If we force an organisation to show us how they make their products, then it will be very unfair to it. For example, KFC is very famous because of its tasty chicken wings. Once this chicken-making restaurant's secret recipe is exposed to the world, then it will damage their profits and reputation. I want to show not only this action is absurd, but, more importantly, this will destroy the fairness of the market. The founder of KFC worked very hard on and spent a lot of time and money on cooking the perfect dish. If all competitors can get this secret for free, this will harm KFC's sales.

In conclusion, although it may seem sensible for us to study techniques, skills, or research without paying money, I personally prefer the current trend in which learners have to pay fee to their teachers.
